intro: Fraxinus pennsylvanica var. ovata, commonly known as the Southern ash or ovate ash, is a deciduous tree native to the southeastern United States. It typically grows to a height of 20–30 meters, featuring a straight trunk and a broad, rounded crown. The leaves are ovate, with a smooth margin and a pointed tip, and they turn yellow in the fall. The tree produces small, greenish-yellow flowers in early spring, followed by winged fruits that disperse its seeds. It is often found in moist, well-drained soils along stream banks and in bottomlands.
